messageBody:
I highly recommend _Working_Effectively_with_Legacy_Code_ by Michael Feathers.
(His definition of "legacy code" is simply "code without tests",
regardless of when it
was written, or by whom.)

That book does an outstanding job of discussing how to get code under test.
The first section, "The Mechanics of Change", describes goals and techniques
of unit testing, along with general strategies for getting tests
around code that
wasn't designed to be tested. The second section, "Changing Software", is
almost a set of case studies. Each chapter addresses a specific problem of the
form, 'I need to ..." or "How do I ..." with clear suggestions and
illustrations.
The third section, " Dependency-Breaking Techniques", returns to the general
level and presents a catalog of tactics for breaking code down into testable
(and manageable) segments.

I sincerely believe the best thing you could do (given your questions) is to
read that book and start trying out the techniques it presents.

Good luck!

-jn-
